history.content:
MATH 54 and CS 70 is enough.

--------

54 and 70 is enough, but you will be at a disadvantage compared to your peers who have taken 126 and 127.

Also, 127 is more directly applicable to 189 in my experience (Shewchuk), but I would still recommend taking both classes.

children.subject: I agree that 127 may gives you more practice of linear algebra, but 189 doesn't necessarily need it. The only concepts I can think of beyond MATH 54 are PSD matrix, quadratic form and SVD, which can be easily learnt on your own.

I disagree with the student answer, that might be enough to get by, but I think having 127 and 126 both will make 189 much more worthwhile since you will understand how things work in more detail, and of 126 and 127, I personally think 127 has been much more useful (gives a better understanding of linear algebra and convexity)

Hmm I've taken STAT 134 and 135 but found them useless to 189... 134 covers very few concepts beyond CS 70, such as order statistics, which is not used in 189. The only part 135 is relevant to 189 is MLE, which is also taught in 189. 135 spends the majority of time on sampling, testing and regression (more about regression analysis, not really relevant to 189).

I agree with you - 135 isn't particularly useful other than the exposure to MLE and OLS. I think classes like Data 100 or Stat 151A (Linear Models) gave me a huge leg up (at least for the FA19 iteration) - just going back over the syllabus, I think I learned more than half of what was covered in 189 in a prior class.

As someone who just took 189, here's what was most useful in order of importance:

1) Linear Algebra (somewhere between math 54 and math 110 level): I'd say this is the most important concept. You will work a lot with matrices and their decompositions, specifically the SVD. Be really comfortable with invertibility and diagonalization. Half the time I felt like our problem sets involved using some form of linear algebra to prove something. 

2) Probability/Statistics (upperdiv level). This is also really important, but not the combinatorics or problem solving part; focus on notions like basic notions of priors/posteriors, Gaussian densities, covariance and correlation, OLS. IMO if your prob/stats background is good, then 189 will be much much easier for you than your fellow classmates. 

3) Optimization (math 53 level): Knowledge of partial derivatives, gradients, and basic knowledge of convexity. I'd argue that optimization is probably just as important as the above two, but ultimately you don't need a high level of understanding to do well in the class.

I think that generally speaking, the students who have the hardest time are those who walk in with the bare minimum prerequisites or have no prior background in statistics. So it really depends on what you want to get out of the class.
Is Math 54 good prep for EE 127? Or do i need EE16A and EE 16B
16A and 16B would probably prepare you better, but if you're not required to take 16A + B I'd recommend taking 54 instead and just putting some extra time into 127 if need be

Math 54 is better than ee16a/b since it teaches linear algebra better as a prereq for 127, also for shewchuks 189 127 is definitely overkill, and he goes over a lot of key linear algebra concepts in lecture, like eigenvalues and stuff

I'm going to have to disagree with Scale here. I've found 127 immensely useful in 127 thus far, and I think a robust understanding of optimisation is essential if you want to know how the theory of machine learning is actually put into practice

Totally fair to disagree! Just know that I and others I know have succeeded and gotten lots out of 189 with shewchuk without 127, so do not feel like you need to put 189 off, especially when it unlocks lots of research opportunities. My suggestion is purely anecdotal, as I am speaking just from my own experience/what I've heard from my friends
Thank you both for the input! One last question.  Does taking it beforehand vs concurrently make a difference?

It varies depending on who is teaching it, but at least for the Shewchuk version I strongly recommend taking EECS 127 before or alongside 189. EECS 126/Prob 140 is useful, but not as useful. Data 100 is p useful. Math 110 is probably unnecessary in the context of 189 (which doesn't mean it is a useless class, just not one to prioritise if you're getting ready to take 189). Math 54 and CS 70 are the bare minimum, but if you take only those two classes you'll have to put in a lot more work to gain from 189, and you'll also (probably) walk away with a shallower understanding of how everything works
I consider myself so blessed to have taken 127 before 189, strongly recommend!

history.content: I am definitely interested in taking CS189 in the future, but having heard it is one of the most difficult classes at Cal, what classes are recommended for me to have taken prior to CS189? I have heard that EECS126 is the most important one to take to prepare for 189, so is that the way to go? What knowledge in mathematics should I prepare myself to learn?
history.subject: What classes should I take to prepare for CS189?
